title: Prado-Pajero Scandal (1995)
description:
The Prado-Pajero Scandal, also known as 'Prado Kand', refers to a major political controversy in Nepal during 1994-1995. The scandal centered on a decision by the coalition government, led by then-Prime Minister Sher Bahadur Deuba, to grant Members of Parliament (MPs) a facility to import vehicles with a 95% customs duty and sales tax exemption.

This privilege was allegedly widely abused. Instead of purchasing vehicles for personal use, an estimated 80% of MPs reportedly sold their duty-free import permits to businessmen and smugglers for personal profit. Many MPs lacked the personal funds, estimated at around Rs 5 million at the time, to purchase the expensive SUVs themselves and effectively acted as intermediaries. This act was seen as a gross abuse of power and a method for the politically unstable government to secure the loyalty of parliamentarians.

The key consequences of the scandal were:

  • A significant loss of state revenue, with some sources claiming it amounted to billions of rupees.
  • Widespread public condemnation and a significant erosion of public trust in the newly restored democratic institutions.
  • The incident is often cited as a 'black spot' in Nepal's political history.

Due to the public outcry and the scale of the misuse, the vehicle exemption facility was later discontinued. The scandal remains a prominent example of policy corruption in Nepal. For more details, see reports from Onlinekhabar and Nepali Times.
unverified_info:
Certain details from initial research could not be independently verified by credible public sources:

  • Specific Financial Loss: An initial claim of a loss of Rs 55 Crore (५५ करोड) could not be corroborated. Available sources generally refer to a loss of "billions" of rupees without providing a precise figure.
  • Involvement of Other Bodies: Allegations regarding the specific involvement of "Parliament officials" (संसद्‌का पदाधिकारी) and the "Army" (सेना) in the scheme could not be confirmed through the available documentation.
key_allegations: Abuse of authority by granting a 95% tax waiver on vehicle imports for MPs.
Members of Parliament selling their duty-free import privilege for personal profit.
Causing significant revenue loss to the state.
Using policy incentives to secure political loyalty in a coalition government.

timeline.title: Deuba Forms Coalition Government
timeline.description: A new coalition government is formed under the leadership of Prime Minister Sher Bahadur Deuba, with support from the Rastriya Prajatantra Party and the Nepal Sadbhawana Party.

timeline.title: Introduction of Tax Waiver and Subsequent Misuse
timeline.description: During Prime Minister Deuba's tenure (1995-1997), his government introduced a policy granting a 95% tax exemption for Members of Parliament to import vehicles. Following this decision, a large number of MPs allegedly sold their import permits to businessmen, leading to the 'Prado-Pajero Scandal'.

sources.title: Onlinekhabar - The most infamous parliament in history: from Prado-Pajero to wine-women
sources.description: An article (in Nepali) detailing various scandals in Nepal's parliamentary history, with a significant section dedicated to the Prado-Pajero scandal. It states that 80% of MPs sold their vehicle import facility.

sources.title: myRepublica - Lawmakers seek tax waiver on personal vehicles
sources.description: A 2017 article referencing the 1994 scandal, stating the Deuba-led government waived 95% of taxes for MPs and that most lawmakers misused the facility to buy Pajero jeeps for businessmen.

sources.title: Nepali Times - Shamelessness
sources.description: A blog post on Nepali Times calling the 'Pajero Scandal' of 1994 a 'black spot' in Nepali politics, where MPs granted themselves duty-free SUV import facilities.
